docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 6 EFFECT OF APPLICATIONS FOR LEAVE AND APPEALS ON COURT BELOW [rr 51.42–51.44]

heading.title: DIVISION 6 EFFECT OF APPLICATIONS FOR LEAVE AND APPEALS ON COURT BELOW [rr 51.42–51.44]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 6 EFFECT OF APPLICATIONS FOR LEAVE AND APPEALS ON COURT BELOW [rr 51.42–51.44]

leg:heading.title: EFFECT OF APPLICATIONS FOR LEAVE AND APPEALS ON COURT BELOW [rr 51.42–51.44]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.42] r 51.42 Copies of notices of intention to appeal, leave applications and summonses to be filed or lodged with court below (cf SCR Part 51, rule 14)

leg:heading.title: Copies of notices of intention to appeal, leave applications and summonses to be filed or lodged with court below (cf SCR Part 51, rule 14)

p.text: A person who files and serves a notice of intention to appeal or relevant originating process must:
where it relates to a decision in a Division of the Supreme Court — file a copy of it in the registry of the Division at the same time, or
in any other case:
file a copy of it in the registry or office of the court below, or
lodge a copy of it with an officer of the court below concerned with its records or process.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.43] r 51.43 Court below to retain exhibits if its decision is appealable (cf SCR Part 51, rule 29)

leg:heading.title: Court below to retain exhibits if its decision is appealable (cf SCR Part 51, rule 29)

p.text: If an appeal from a decision lies to the Court, by leave or otherwise, the officer of the court below who has custody of the exhibits in the proceedings must, unless the court below orders otherwise, retain them for:
28 days after the material date, and
if a notice of intention to appeal is filed or lodged — a further 3 months.
On the filing or lodgment under rule 51.42 of a copy of a notice of appeal, the proper officer of the court below must make out and certify a list of the exhibits.
If an exhibit is not available, the officer certifying must include such information as the officer can to enable the Registrar to obtain the exhibit.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.44] r 51.44 Appeal proceedings do not operate as stay unless Court or court below directs (cf SCR Part 51, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Appeal proceedings do not operate as stay unless Court or court below directs (cf SCR Part 51, rule 15)

p.text: Subject to the filing of a relevant originating process, the Court may order that the decision below or the proceedings under the decision be stayed.
The filing of a relevant originating process does not:
operate as a stay of proceedings under the decision below, or
invalidate any intermediate act or proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [51.44.5] Stay pending appeal — power to grant

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.44.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 51.2.

heading.title: Stay pending appeal — power to grant

level.toc-caption: [51.44.10] Stay application to the trial judge

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.44.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 135.

heading.title: Stay application to the trial judge

p.text: It is usually appropriate for stay applications to be made, at least in the first instance, to the trial judge: Frith v Sipple (NSWCA, Moffitt P, Hutley and Mahoney JJA, 11 September 1978, CA No 210/78, unreported) (at [456,125] behind guide card “Practice Decisions” in vol 3). An obvious reason for this is that the trial judge will know the circumstances of the case and be well aware of the factors relevant to the exercise of the discretion to grant or refuse a stay. Indeed, it is not uncommon for judges at first instance to provide a stay for a limited period, in order to allow the unsuccessful party a reasonable opportunity to assess the prospects of an appeal: see for example, Goldstein v Craft (1926) 26 SR (NSW) 354 at 362 (where Street CJ referred to, and explained, the expression “stay on the usual terms”). It would seem that the trial judge's power to grant a stay continues even after the institution of an appeal: Holmark Constructions Pty Ltd v Tsoukaris (1986) 12 NSWLR 181 and see CPA s 135 . The refusal of a stay by the trial judge does not preclude a further application being made to the Court of Appeal (Alexander v Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 685 at 692; 10 ACLR 42 ; Cropper v Smith (1883) 24 Ch D 305 ; Cox v Mosman [1908] St R Qd 211; JC Scott Constructions v Mermaid Waters Tavern Pty Ltd (No 2) [1983] 2 Qd R 255 ) which has an inherent or incidental power to order a stay whenever justice requires: Tringali v Stewardson Stubbs & Collett Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 354; (1966) 66 SR (NSW) 335 ; Ferris v Lambton (1905) 22 WN (NSW) 56 ; Alexander v Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd (recs apptd) (1985) 2 NSWLR 685; 10 ACLR 42 (large money judgment, variation of conditions imposed upon the grant of stay by a judge at first instance). The exercise of that power will be particularly appropriate where it is necessary to maintain an existing state of affairs in order to preserve the subject matter of the proceedings: Paringa Mining and Exploration Co Plc v North Flinders Mines Ltd (No 2) (1988) 165 CLR 452; 81 ALR 609; BC8802648 ; Kalifair Pty Ltd v Digi-Tech (Aust) Ltd (2002) 55 NSWLR 737; [2002] NSWCA 383; BC200207367 .

In order to justify a stay, an applicant must identify the circumstances that warrant a departure from the general rule that the judgment below should be presumed to be correct and is appropriate to be enforced: Klinker Knitting Mills Pty Ltd v L'Union Fire Accident and General Insurance Co Ltd [1937] VLR 142; [1937] ALR 298 ; Barker v Lavery (1885) 14 QBD 769 ; Atkins v Great Western Railway (1886) 2 TLR 400 ; Wilson v Church (No 2) (1879) 12 Ch D 454 ; Amoco Australia Pty Ltd v Rocca Bros Motor Engineering Co Pty Ltd (1972) 7 SASR 268 ; JC Scott Constructions v Mermaid Waters Tavern Pty Ltd (No 1) [1983] 2 Qd R 243 .

An appellant applicant does not have to show that the circumstances relied on to support a judgment stay can properly be described as “special” or “exceptional”: Alexander v Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 685; 10 ACLR 42 ; Powerflex Services Pty Ltd v Data Access Corporation (1996) 67 FCR 65; 137 ALR 498; 35 IPR 193; BC9602459 . An appellant’s ability to identify reasonably arguable grounds of appeal is highly relevant to the exercise of the stay discretion: Andrews v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 184 ; Alexander v Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 685 at 695; 10 ACLR 42 . The existence of arguable grounds of appeal is not necessarily sufficient to justify the grant of a stay: McBride v Sandland (No 2) (1918) 25 CLR 369, at 374; 25 ALR 54; BC1800006 . But their absence is likely to be a determinative consideration against the stay application: Chen v Lym International Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 121; BC200904486 at [15] per Beazley JA; Trad v Harbour Radio Pty Ltd [2010] NSWCA 41; BC201001404 at [48] per Tobias JA; Alexander v Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 685 at 695; 10 ACLR 42 .
Circumstances sufficient to justify the grant of a stay exist where:
refusal would render the appeal futile: Wilson v Church (No 2) (1879) 12 Ch D 454 ; Re Middle Harbour Investments Ltd (in liq) (NSWCA, 15 December 1976, unreported);

where money paid to a respondent to satisfy the judgment may be irrecoverable if the appeal is successful: TCN Channel 9 v Antoniadis (No 2) (1999) 48 NSWLR 381; [1999] NSWCA 104; BC9901834 ; Linotype-Hill Finance Ltd v Baker (Practice Note) [1992] 4 All ER 887; [1993] 1 WLR 321 ; Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations Incorporated v Tobacco Institute of Australia Ltd (No2) (1991) 30 FCR 548; ATPR 41-138 ; Penrith Whitewater Stadium Ltd v Lesvos Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 103; BC200703149 (sufficient evidence of insolvency to establish risk that judgment would not be repaid if not stayed — bank guarantee provided as security for costs not released);

refusal of a stay may result in the subject matter of the action being lost: Scarborough v Lew's Junction Stores Pty Ltd [1963] VR 129 ; The Annot Lyle, above; Polini v Gray; Sturlan v Freccia (1879) 12 Ch D 438 at 446 ; Erinford Properties Ltd v Cheshire County Council [1974] Ch 261; [1974] 2 All ER 448; [1974] 2 WLR 749 ; Bercove v Hermes (No 2) (1983) 51 ALR 105; 78 FLR 232; 5 ALN No 227 ; G E Trade Mark, Re [1970] RPC 339 ;

to refuse a stay would deprive the appellant of the means of prosecuting the appeal: Emmerson v Ind Coope (1886) 55 LJ Ch 905; Smith Hogg & Co v Black Sea & Baltic General Insurance Co (1940) 162 LT 11 ; Youssoupoff v MGM Pictures Ltd (1934) 50 TLR 581 at 588 ;

refusal of a stay would impose irreparable harm in the event the appeal was successful: FAI Insurances Ltd v Registrar of Workers Compensation Commission of NSW [1982] 1 NSWLR 239 (appeal against cancellation of insurance licence); Kalifair Pty Ltd v Digi-Tech (Aust) Ltd (2002) 55 NSWLR 737 at 741–2; [2002] NSWCA 383; BC200207367 (stay necessary to prevent corporate defendant being placed in liquidation);

perhaps, there is an outstanding cross-claim against the respondent: JC Scott Constructions v Mermaid Waters Tavern Pty Ltd (No 2) [1983] 2 Qd R 255 at 259 ; Debtor, Re a; Ex parte Petitioning Creditors v Debtor [1951] Ch 612 ; Joskovitz v Bonnick [1964] VR 654 ; Automatic Weighing Machine Co v Combined Weighing & Advertising Machine Co (1889) 58 LJ Ch 647; 61 LT 536; 6 RPC 367; [1886-90] All ER Rep Ext 1343 ; Grant v Banque Franco-Egyptienne (1878) 3 CPD 202 ;

to refuse the stay would cause one or other of the parties to incur a significant financial burden: Chen v Lym International [2009] NSWCA 121; BC200904486 at [40] (order for transfer of land — potential liability for stamp duty on transfer and retransfer).

The overriding principle in any stay application is that of upholding the interests of justice in the particular circumstances: New South Wales Bar Assn v Stevens (2003) 52 ATR 602; [2003] NSWCA 95; BC200301897 at [83] . Where those circumstances include the fact that the order below has been made in the context of regulatory proceedings taken in the public interest, and is based on findings of substantial impropriety, the protection of the public is a matter entitled to significant weight: see Bannister v Walton (NSWCA, Mahoney, Sheller, Cripps JJA, 40207/1992, 30 April 1992, unreported, BC9201911); Sinha v Health Care Complaints Commission [2001] NSWCA 48; BC200100936 ; Stevens, above at [90]–[104]; see also Bryant v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1996) 134 ALR 460; 70 ALJR 306 at 309; BC9600435 ; Sibuse v Shaw (No 2) (1988) 13 NSWLR 125; BC8801898 .

level.toc-caption: [51.44.25] Stay upon terms — part payment, security and restitution

heading.title: Stay upon terms — part payment, security and restitution

p.text: A stay justified by the principles considered in [51.44.5] and [51.44.15] may be subject to terms requiring payment of part of the judgment debt: Doyle v White City Stadium Ltd [1935] 1 KB 110 ; Bloor v Liverpool Derricking and Carrying Co Ltd [1936] 3 All ER 399 ; Andrews v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 184 ; or to terms requiring security for the judgment debt: Rosengrens Ltd v Safe Deposit Centres Ltd [1984] 3 All ER 198; [1984] 1 WLR 1334 . As an alternative to staying payment under the judgment, the court may require a respondent to give an undertaking, or security, for repayment if the appeal succeeds: Merry v Nickalls (1873) LR 8 Ch App 206; Cooper v Cooper (1876) 2 Ch D 493; Swyny v Harland [1894] 1 QB 707 . If payment is not stayed, and part of the judgment proceeds are likely to be paid to the respondent's creditors (especially the respondent's solicitors), it is appropriate to require the creditor to undertake to repay: TCN Channel 9 Pty Ltd v Antoniadis (No 2) (1999) 48 NSWLR 381 at 385; [1999] NSWCA 104; BC9901834 ; Hood-Barrs v Crossman [1897] AC 172 at 176 ; (undertaking may be required from respondent’s solicitor) and in the absence of such an undertaking the creditors cannot be ordered to repay: Attorney-General v Emerson (1889) 24 QBD 56 ; Hood Barrs v Crossman , above; Morgan v Elford (1876) 4 Ch D 352 ; Grant v Banque Franco-Egyptienne (1878) 3 CPD 202 . Such an undertaking operates only between the parties and is not an undertaking to the court: Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden [1999] NSWCA 319; BC9906208 .

If an interlocutory injunction is granted and then proceedings are dismissed, it will generally be appropriate to continue a similar injunction pending an appeal — provided the court is satisfied that there are arguable grounds of appeal: Jesasu Pty Ltd v Minister for Mineral Resources (1987) 11 NSWLR 110 . Similarly, the court below has jurisdiction to grant a further injunction until the appeal is heard, in order to maintain the status quo: Orion Property Trust Ltd v Du Cane Court Ltd [1962] 3 All ER 466; [1962] 1 WLR 1085 ; Erinford Properties Ltd v Cheshire County Council [1974] Ch 261 . Any determination of the trial judge to grant, or refuse, such an injunction is subject to any contrary order by the Court of Appeal: Alexander v Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd (1985) 2 NSWLR 685 at 692; 10 ACLR 42 ; Paringa Mining and Exploration Co Plc v North Flinders Mines Ltd (No 2) (1988) 165 CLR 452 at 459; 81 ALR 609; BC8802648 (“it is not satisfactory to leave to the judge whose orders are under review the exercise of the appellate discretion to grant or refuse the injunction pending the appeal”).

It has been said that there will rarely be circumstances in which it will be appropriate to stay the operation of a merely declaratory order. The true position is that the availability of a stay must always depend upon the particular circumstances of the case: Bunnings Forest Products Pty Ltd v Bullen (1994) 54 FCR 342; 126 ALR 660; BC9400209 .

level.toc-caption: [51.44.40] Applications for leave to appeal — interlocutory orders

heading.title: Applications for leave to appeal — interlocutory orders

p.text: A stay will not normally be granted, nor will expedition be ordered, where it is sought to appeal against a ruling in committal proceedings, or in civil proceedings, where the main hearing of the proceedings will be delayed: Partnership Pacific Ltd v Killen (NSWCA, Moffitt P, Reynolds and Hutley JJA,10 April 1979,CA No 112/79, unreported) (at [456,165] behind guide card “Practice Decisions” in vol 3).

level.toc-caption: [51.44.45] Stay pending appeal to the High Court

heading.title: Stay pending appeal to the High Court

p.text: The court may deal with an application for a stay pending an application for special leave to appeal to the High Court: Jennings Constructions Ltd v Burgundy Royale Investments Pty Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 681 at 684; 69 ALR 265; 61 ALJR 102 at 103; BC8601399 ; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Kelly (No 2) (1987) 8 NSWLR 510 ; cf Sibuse v Shaw (No 2) (1988) 13 NSWLR 125; BC8801898 .

The High Court has encouraged intermediate appellate courts to deal with stay applications of this kind: Jennings Constructions Ltd v Burgundy Royale Investments Pty Ltd , above, at 684; Smith Kline & French Laboratories (Aust) Ltd v Department of Community Services (1991) 99 ALR 417 at 421; 65 ALJR 360 ; Minister for Local Government v South Sydney City Council (No 3) [2002] NSWCA 327; BC200205823 at [27]–[28] per Spigelman CJ. That encouragement has resulted in intermediate courts recognising, without diffidence, their function in exercising the power to stay proceedings pending applications for leave to appeal: Saleh v Romanous [2010] NSWCA 373; BC201009912 at [22]–[26] (stay granted); Miller v Nationwide News Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 261; BC200809152 and Bennette v Cohen (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 162; BC200905421 at [63]–[65] . This is so, notwithstanding the difficulty that may sometimes be occasioned for a member of an intermediate court of appeal in making an assessment of the prospects of a grant of special leave in a particular case: Minister of Local Government v South Sydney City Council (No 3) , above, at [11]; Tyndall v ACN 062 895 774 Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 102; BC200703150 at [13]–[14] . See Adeels Palace Pty Ltd v Moubarak (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 130; BC200904578 (stay granted, conditions imposed) and S v NSW (No 5) [2009] NSWCA 308; BC200908722 (stay granted).

The principles applicable to the grant of a stay (Jennings Constructions Ltd v Burgundy Royale Investments Pty Ltd , above at 684–5) and of an injunction (Smith Kline & French Laboratories (Aust) Ltd v Department of Community Services and Health , above, at 419) substantially overlap: Minister of Local Government v South Sydney City Council (No 3) [2002] NSWCA 327; BC200205823 at [10] ; Tyndall v ACN 062 895 774 Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 102; BC200703150 at [12] per McColl JA. They require consideration of:
the relevantly “extraordinary” nature of the stay power: see Jennings Constructions Ltd v Burgundy Royale Investments Pty Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 681 at 684; 69 ALR 265; 61 ALJR 102; BC8601399 ;
prospects of a grant of special leave;
the prospects of success on appeal;
the effect of not granting a stay or an injunction on the rights, obligations or interests of the respective parties;
the “balance of convenience”.

The extraordinary nature of the stay power, together with the High Court’s encouragement, dictates that intermediate courts should not approach their exercise of the stay power on the basis of making a merely interim decision for the purpose of facilitating an application to the High Court: Rinehart v Welker [2012] NSWCA 1; BC201200118 at [22]–[47] .
The stay applicant’s prospect of success is clearly a material, and potentially determinative, consideration in the exercise of the power: Rinehart v Welker , above at [48]–[70].

In assessing the materiality to the parties of a decision to stay, or refuse to stay, the decisions below show that various verbal formulations have been used. Commonly, the purpose of the application will be characterised as “preserving the subject-matter of the litigation” (see Jennings Constructions Ltd v Burgundy Royale Investments Pty Ltd , above, at 685, and Smith Kline & French Laboratories (Aust) Ltd v Department of Community Services and Health , above, at 419). Other expressions, all intended to convey the same idea (that refusal of a stay will have a substantial, irremediable and adverse effect) and describe the relevant consideration as:
“preserving the integrity of the litigation”: see Advanced Building Systems Pty Ltd v Ramset Fasteners (Aust) Pty Ltd (1997) 145 ALR 121; 71 ALJR 814 at 815; [1997] 14 Leg Rep 38; BC9702855 ;

avoiding a “real risk that it is not possible for a successful appellant to be restored substantially to his, her or its former position”: see Federal Commissioner of Taxation v Myer Emporium Ltd (1986) 160 CLR 220 at 223; 64 ALR 325; 60 ALJR 300; BC8601417 per Dawson J;

avoiding the “futility” of the appeal: Patrick Stevedore Operations No 2 Pty Ltd v Maritime Union of Australia (1998) 72 ALJR 869; [1998] 9 Leg Rep 2b; (1998) 79 IR 411; BC9801579 at [3] per Hayne J; Ampolex Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (1996) 137 ALR 28; 70 ALJR 603 at 606; [1996] 10 Leg Rep 15; BC9602403 per Kirby J and see (to the same effect) Minister of Local Government v South Sydney City Council (No 3) [2002] NSWCA 327; BC200205823 at [12]–[14] ; Tyndall v ACN 062 895 774 Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 102; BC200703150 at [13]–[14] per McColl JA.
